The eight causes and reasons that lead t: Living relying on the Teacher or a spiritual companion in a teacher’s role
Asking questions from time to time
Perfecting withdrawal of both body and mind
Being ethical and restrained in the monastic code
Being very learned and remembering what they’ve learned
Living with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities
Not engaging in motley talk or unworthy talk when in the Saṅgha
Meditating observing rise and fall in the five grasping aggregates
Qualities that lead to fondness, respect: Living relying on the Teacher or a spiritual companion in a teacher’s role, and setting up a keen sense of conscience and prudence for them, with warmth and respect
Going and asking questions from time to time
Perfecting withdrawal of both body and mind after hearing the teaching
Being ethical and restrained in the monastic code
Being very learned and remembering what they’ve learned
Living with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities
Not engaging in motley talk or unworthy talk when in the Saṅgha
Meditating observing rise and fall in the five grasping aggregates.
